intro: Euplassa organensis, commonly known as the Organ Mountains dandelion, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in rocky and arid environments, showcasing adaptations to harsh desert conditions. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are yellow and bloom in early spring. Euplassa organensis plays a role in local ecosystems by providing nectar for pollinators and serving as a food source for small herbivores.
